answers.text: Both planes will move one space along the grid, then stop.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. These sprites have "behaviors" which keep running until they are told to stop.

answers.text: Both planes will start moving and not stop.
answers.feedback: Correct! These behaviors tell the planes to start moving and keep going.

answers.text: One plane will move first, and the other plane will move later.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. Each block of code in Sprite Lab runs instantly after the next.

answers.text: The planes will crash.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. The planes are not positioned in a way that will make them touch.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2023/l.short_instructions: Give a sprite a behavior.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2023/l.long_instructions:
# Behaviors Sprites can have their own behaviors, which are actions they will do over and over while the program runs. To give a sprite a behavior, you need to use a `sprite begins` block with a behavior block. ## Do This
[expandable][0][expandable][1][expandable][2]
- Drag out a `sprite begins` block from the **Behaviors** toolbox category. - Drag out a green behavior block. Connect the blocks in your workspace. - Press "Run" to see what happens. - Explore different behaviors to see what they do. - _Challenge:_ Have your sprite begin two different behaviors at the same time.

courseF_sprites_clouds_2023.short_instructions: Make the cloud move across the screen. Make the sun spin. Make the butterfly wander around.
courseF_sprites_clouds_2023.long_instructions:
# A Breezy Day
![expandable](https://images.code.org/bd7f7bb8b6e56028ad7f6c7ef8ac7eb8-image-1610401074711.gif)
There is already code to create the sprites. Add to this program to give each sprite a behavior. ## Do This * Add a `sprite begins` block for each sprite costume in your program. * Pick behaviors for each sprite: * Make the cloud move across the screen. * Make the sun spin. * Make the butterfly wander around. * *Bonus:* Use additional behaviors to make the butterfly appear more life-like.

authored_hints.behavior_list: Try using behaviors such as "moving east and looping", "spinning right", and "wandering".

answers.text: The sprite will just spin right.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. The sprite will also move east.

answers.text: The sprite will just move east.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. The sprite has not stopped spinning, so it will do both simultaneously.

answers.text: The sprite will spin and move at the same time.
answers.feedback: Correct! Both behaviors will happen simultaneously.

answers.text: The sprite will spin first and then move later.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. In Sprite Lab, connected blocks happen immediately after each the last one, so both behaviors will happen simultaneously.

# Time Events
[expandable][0]
Events make it easy to change what happens over time as your program runs. Use an [blockly block][1] event to make the sprite begin a new behavior after some time has passed. ## Do This - Add an `at 3 seconds` event block to your workspace. - Connect a `sprite begins` block under this event. The sprite should begin a second behavior after some time has passed.

# Key Events
[expandable][0]
Events make it possible to create programs that are interactive. Use the [blockly block][1] event block to change the sprite's _size_, _position_, or _rotation_ when the user presses a key. ## Do This - Add a `when key pressed` **event** block to your workspace. - Connect a `change` block under this event. - Press the arrow keys on your screen or keyboard after pressing Run.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2023/l.long_instructions:
# Switching Behaviors
[expandable][0]
If you want to switch from one behavior to another, you need to _stop_ the old behavior and _begin_ the new behavior at the same time. You can use a new block to make sprites stop their current behaviors. [blockly block][1] You'll need to connect a behavior to this block, such as `moving east`. ## Do This - Run the code and see what happens. - Add behaviors to each `stops` and `begins` block to make the sprite change from moving east to moving west at 2 seconds.

# Opposite Behaviors
[expandable][0]
Some behaviors do opposite things, like `moving east`/`moving west`, `growing`/`shrinking`, or `spinning right`/`spinning left`. If a sprite has two opposite behaviors it might seem like the sprite isn't doing anything at all. ## Do This - Run the code and see what happens at 3 seconds. - Add a `sprite stops` block under the event. - Use this block to stop the old behavior. _The sprite should now spin one way, then another way._

courseF_events_choice_conflict_2023.long_instructions:
# Do a Barrel Roll!
![expandable](https://images.code.org/08b3e8a6ed02260555675174a0a41c13-image-1611354854787.2021-01-22 17_33_41.gif)
Let's make the plane sprite spin left when you press one key, and right when you press the other key. Do you remember this block? "creature_18_1" ## Do This * Read the code below carefully. * Run the code and press both arrows to see what happens.
What's the bug?When you press the first arrow key, the plane spins, but the program stops working when you press the second arrow key.
* Add an `sprite stops` block under each event. * Use this block to stop the opposite behavior. *The sprite should now spin in either direction when you press each arrow key.*

courseF_events_choice_conflict2_2023.bubble_choice_description: Make the sprite change sizes with the arrow keys. Practice controlling behaviors with events.
courseF_events_choice_conflict2_2023.short_instructions: Make the sprite shrink when you press one key, and grow when you press the other key.
courseF_events_choice_conflict2_2023.long_instructions:
# Shrink and Grow
![expandable](https://images.code.org/ee8148a40007249560471e6a99b537e3-image-1611697250512.2021-01-26 16_38_41.gif)
Let's make the sprite shrink when you press one key, and grow when you press the other key. Do you remember this block? "creature_05_1" ## Do This * Read the code below carefully. * Run the code and press both arrows to see what happens.
What's the bug?When you press an arrow key, the sprite begins one behavior. When you press the second arrow key, the sprite seems to stop responding.
* Add an `sprite stops` block under each event. * Use this block to stop the opposite behavior. *The sprite should now shrink or grow when you press each arrow key.*

courseF_events_choice_pufferfish_2023.bubble_choice_description: Make the pufferfish quickly expand in size! Practice using events.
courseF_events_choice_pufferfish_2023.short_instructions: Use the "while key pressed" event block to repeatedly change the sprite's size while the user presses a key.
courseF_events_choice_pufferfish_2023.long_instructions:
# When vs. While
![expandable](https://images.code.org/ecd2788bd12f594a846de079ed22f484-image-1611328367728.2021-01-22 10_12_02.gif)
The when/while??? block has two important options. It can be triggered "when" a key is first pressed (one time) or "while" the key is pressed (over and over again). Setting this block to "while" can make your interactive animations faster and smoother. Use the `when/while key pressed` event block to repeatedly change the sprite's *size* while the user presses a key. ## Do This * Add a `key pressed` event to your workspace. Set it to either "when" or while". * Connect a `change size by` **action** block under this event. * Press the arrow keys on your screen or keyboard after pressing Run. *Extra Challenge:* Make the sprite get bigger when you press "up" and smaller when you press "down".

courseF_events_choice_penguin_2023.short_instructions: Change each "when key pressed" block to "while key pressed" to make the sprite's movement faster and smoother.
courseF_events_choice_penguin_2023.long_instructions:
# When vs. While
![expandable](https://images.code.org/a81a5d5487327d7783540239d87a988e-image-1611351171916.2021-01-22 16_31_44.gif)
The when/while??? has two important options. It can be triggered "when" a key is first pressed (one time) or "while" the key is pressed (over and over again). Setting this block to "while" can make your interactive animations faster and smoother. The `when key pressed` event block makes the sprite move with the keys, but it feels slow and clunky. ## Do This * Run the program and press the arrow keys to see how the sprite moves. * Change each `when key pressed` block to `while key pressed` to make the sprite's movement faster and smoother.

This lesson contains a **mini-project**. This progression may feel very different from what has come earlier in the course for you as well as your students. These levels have some new characteristics you may want to explore before starting. 

-   The code your students write in one level will automatically transfer over to the other levels. This allows them to build gradually and iterate on their ideas as they learn.
-   These levels allow for more open-ended creativity. Empower your students to determine for themselves when they have completed each task. There is no one right answer! 
-   Example solutions are available for this step of the progression which can be viewed by opening the teacher panel to the right.

# Prompts (Part 1)
[expandable][0]
It's time to start learning how to use **prompts**. Prompts make it possible to get words and other text from the user and use them later in your program. The text the user types into the prompt is stored in a **variable**. [blockly block][1] ## Do This - Find the `prompt user` block in the **World** category and add it to your program. - In the top part of the block, type in a question you'd like to ask. - Change `???` to the label you want to use by clicking "**Rename this variable**." - Press "Run", then answer the prompt by typing something in. _Nothing else will happen yet, but that's okay!_

Your completed plan should include: * The type of project you're building. courseF_variables_card_finish_2023.bubble_choice_description: Put the finishing touches on your project, then share it!
courseF_variables_card_finish_2023.long_instructions:
# Finish Your Greeting Card

*You should have already started building your greeting card program. If you haven't, return to the [previous level](../sublevel/1).*


You can now add whatever you like to your code. Your card can ask the user multiple questions and respond with a message for each one. You can make your program more interactive, by changing the behaviors of your sprites with each event, or by adding sounds and backgrounds. If you would like a new idea, click the lightbulb to the left.

authored_hints.card_idea1:
You can add a second (or third or fourth) prompt by connecting a new prompt block with a different variable to your first `when answered` event.

<xml><block type="gamelab_whenPromptAnswered">
    <value name="VAR">
      <block type="variables_get" can_disconnect_from_parent="false">
        <title name="VAR">name</title>
      </block>
    </value>
    <next>
      <block type="gamelab_setPrompt">
        <value name="QUESTION">
          <block type="text" can_disconnect_from_parent="false">
            <title name="TEXT">what do you want for your birthday?</title>
          </block>
        </value>
        <value name="VAR">
          <block type="variables_get" can_disconnect_from_parent="false">
            <title name="VAR">gift</title>
          </block>
        </value>
      </block>
    </next>
  </block></xml>
authored_hints.card_idea2:
You can have a change from one behavior to another by using a `sprite stops` block with a `sprite begins` block under an event.

<xml><block type="gamelab_whenPromptAnswered">
    <value name="VAR">
      <block type="variables_get" can_disconnect_from_parent="false">
        <title name="VAR">name</title>
      </block>
    </value>
    <next>
      <block type="gamelab_removeBehaviorSimple">
        <value name="SPRITE">
          <block type="gamelab_allSpritesWithAnimation">
            <title name="ANIMATION">"robot_02_1"</title>
          </block>
        </value>
        <value name="BEHAVIOR">
          <block type="gamelab_behavior_get">
            <mutation></mutation>
            <title name="VAR" id="spinning left">spinning left</title>
          </block>
        </value>
        <next>
          <block type="gamelab_addBehaviorSimple">
            <value name="SPRITE">
              <block type="gamelab_allSpritesWithAnimation">
                <title name="ANIMATION">"robot_02_1"</title>
              </block>
            </value>
            <value name="BEHAVIOR">
              <block type="gamelab_behavior_get">
                <mutation></mutation>
                <title name="VAR" id="spinning right">spinning right</title>
              </block>
            </value>
          </block>
        </next>
      </block>
    </next>
  </block>
</xml>
authored_hints.card_idea3:
You can make your program interactive by making other things happen when the user presses a key or after a certain amount of time has passed.

<xml><block type="gamelab_keyPressed">
    <title name="CONDITION">"when"</title>
    <title name="KEY">"up"</title>
    <next>
      <block type="gamelab_changePropBy">
        <title name="PROPERTY">"scale"</title>
        <value name="SPRITE">
          <block type="gamelab_allSpritesWithAnimation">
            <title name="ANIMATION">"robot_02_1"</title>
          </block>
        </value>
        <value name="VAL">
          <block type="math_number">
            <title name="NUM">10</title>
          </block>
        </value>
      </block>
    </next>
  </block></xml>

courseF_variables_madlib_2023.bubble_choice_description: Create your first prompt, then add sprites and behaviors.
courseF_variables_madlib_2023.short_instructions: Create an interactive blank space story!
courseF_variables_madlib_2023.long_instructions:
# Create a blank space story! You can use Sprite Lab to create to bring your own blank space story to life. Using variables, your project will ask the user for words that get worked into a silly story. Create your program below. This works best if you already have a plan to follow. You will also need to draw your own sprite costume, or add a new one that you like. Look for the "*People*" category!*

People

## Requirements * Your program needs to ask the user at least one question. * Your program needs to print text from at least one variable. * Your program needs to include sprites with behaviors. You can also add whatever you like to your code, including backgrounds, sounds, and more.

courseF_variables_madlib_finish_2023.bubble_choice_description: Put the finishing touches on your project, then share it!
courseF_variables_madlib_finish_2023.short_instructions: Finish your customized blank space story.
courseF_variables_madlib_finish_2023.long_instructions:
# Finish Your Blank Space Story

*You should have already started building your interactive blank space story. If you haven't, return to the [previous level](../sublevel/5).*


You can now add whatever you like to your code. Ask the user for multiple words, and use each one in a story you print to the screen. You can make your program more interactive, by changing the behaviors of your sprite with each event, or by adding sounds and backgrounds. If you would like a new idea, click the lightbulb to the left.

authored_hints.card_idea1:
You can add a second (or third or fourth) prompt by using a new prompt block with a different variable.

<xml>
      <block type="gamelab_setPrompt">
        <value name="QUESTION">
          <block type="text" can_disconnect_from_parent="false">
            <title name="TEXT">Enter an action word:</title>
          </block>
        </value>
        <value name="VAR">
          <block type="variables_get" can_disconnect_from_parent="false">
            <title name="VAR">verb</title>
          </block>
        </value>
      </block>
    </xml>
authored_hints.card_idea2:
You can have a change from one behavior to another by using a `sprite stops` block with a `sprite begins` block under an event.

<xml><block type="gamelab_whenPromptAnswered">
    <value name="VAR">
      <block type="variables_get" can_disconnect_from_parent="false">
        <title name="VAR">name</title>
      </block>
    </value>
    <next>
      <block type="gamelab_removeBehaviorSimple">
        <value name="SPRITE">
          <block type="gamelab_allSpritesWithAnimation">
            <title name="ANIMATION">"robot_02_1"</title>
          </block>
        </value>
        <value name="BEHAVIOR">
          <block type="gamelab_behavior_get">
            <mutation></mutation>
            <title name="VAR" id="spinning left">spinning left</title>
          </block>
        </value>
        <next>
          <block type="gamelab_addBehaviorSimple">
            <value name="SPRITE">
              <block type="gamelab_allSpritesWithAnimation">
                <title name="ANIMATION">"robot_02_1"</title>
              </block>
            </value>
            <value name="BEHAVIOR">
              <block type="gamelab_behavior_get">
                <mutation></mutation>
                <title name="VAR" id="spinning right">spinning right</title>
              </block>
            </value>
          </block>
        </next>
      </block>
    </next>
  </block>
</xml>

# Counting with Variables

Let's learn to use **variables** with numbers! Remember that **variables** are labels for information used in a program. This new block allows you to store a value in a variable without using a prompt.

[blockly block][0]

## Do This

-   Drag a `set` block into the workspace and connect it under `when run`.
-   Change `???` to `count` or another label.
-   Make the bunny sprite `say` the number that is stored in the variable.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2023/l.short_instructions: Build a program that changes a variable's value over time. Make the sprite say the new value when it changes.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2023/l.long_instructions:
The value stored in a **variable** can change over time. Let's build a program that uses the same variable multiple times. A new block has been added to the **Variables** section of your toolbox:

[blockly block][0]

This blocks _adds_ another number to the value stored in a variable. It only works when the variable is used to store a number.

## Do This

-   Connect a `change by` block under the `at 4 seconds` event block.
    -   Use the same _label_ for each variable block in your program.
-   Connect a `say` block under the `change by` block.
    -   Make the sprite say the value of the variable after it is changed.
-   Press "Run", then wait 4 seconds. Your sprite should say a new number.

This program makes the sprite say the value of `count` each time it is clicked, but the sprite is saying the same number each time. What block can you add to the program to make the sprite say a different number each time it is clicked?

## Do This

-   Make your program change the value of the variable each time the sprite is clicked.
-   Press "Run", then click your sprite repeatedly to make it count!

_Extra challenge:_ Change `when clicked` to `while clicked` to make the sprite count rapidly.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2023/l.long_instructions:
# Carrot Clicker

In the second half of this lesson, you will create a "clicker game" that others can play! In a clicker game, the user scores points by clicking sprites to remove them. The code here is an example of a finished game like what you might build. You will be able to choose different sprite costumes and customize the rules of your game.

## Do This

-   Read through the code and make a prediction about how it works.
-   Press "Run" and play the game by clicking the sprites. How many points can you score?
-   _Optional:_ Make changes to the code, such as using a different sprite costume or making a different number of sprites.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2023/l.short_instructions: Create a group of sprites with the same costume.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2023/l.long_instructions:
# Create a clicker game

You're going to make a game. The user will click sprites quickly to score as many points as they can! To start, let's create a group of sprites with the same costume.

## Do This

-   Use the `make new sprites` block to create a group of sprites.
-   _Optional:_ Change the size of your sprites to make them harder or easier to click.
-   _Optional:_ Set a background for your game.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2023/l.short_instructions: Use a variable to set the player's score at the beginning of the game and to give them points each time they click a sprite.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2023/l.long_instructions:
# Remove clicked sprites

In this game, we will remove sprites when they are clicked. The user will click sprites quickly to score as many points as they can!

## Do This

-   Drag a `when clicked` event block from the toolbox to your workspace.
-   Drag a `remove` block from the toolbox to your event block.
-   Open the event block. Drag `clicked sprite` block from inside to the `remove` block.
-   Press "Run" to test your game so far. Click the sprites to remove them.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2023/l.short_instructions: Use a variable to set the player's score at the beginning of the game and to give them points each time they click a sprite.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2023/l.long_instructions:
# Track the score with a variable

You need to keep track of the player's score. Let's use a variable to do two things:

1.  Set the score to 0 at the beginning of the game.
2.  Give a point each time the user clicks a sprite.

## Do This

_Under `when run`:_

-   Set a variable like `score` to 0.

_Under `when clicked`:_

-   Give the user points by changing the same variable.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2023/l.short_instructions: After enough time has passed, end this game by printing the player's final score.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2023/l.long_instructions:
# End the game

Eventually, games come to an end. After enough time has passed, we can end this game by printing the player's final score.

## Do This

-   Drag an `at seconds` block to your workspace. Choose the number of seconds that your game should last.
-   Under `at seconds`, use a `print` block to show the player's score.

_Extra Challenge:_ Combine other text with your variable to congratulate the player.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2023/l.long_instructions:
# Finish your Clicker Game

You can now add whatever you like to your code. For example, you can change the background to a `random color` every time you click a sprite. You can also add sounds that play at the beginning and end of the game, or when you click a sprite.

If you would like a new idea, click the light bulb to the left.

authored_hints.clicker_backsgrounds_hint:
Make your game flashy by setting the background to a `random color` each time a sprite is clicked.

[blockly block][0]
authored_hints.clicker_sounds_hint:
Add sounds to different parts of your game by connecting a `play sound` block under each event.

[blockly block][0]
authored_hints.clicker_extend_hint:
Do you want a longer game? Make more and more sprites after a certain amount of time has passed.

[blockly block][0]
authored_hints.clicker_remove_hint:
When your game ends, you can remove all the remaining sprites like this:

[blockly block][0]

https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2023/l.short_instructions: Make exactly one "player" sprite. Give the sprite a behavior that matches the kind of movement you'd like to have.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2023/l.long_instructions:
# Create the "Player" Your game will have a "player" sprite that the user will move around by pressing the arrow keys or dragging with the mouse. You can use a bunny costume for this sprite, or choose something different from the **Costumes** tab. ## Do This ### Costumes tab - _Optional:_ Add at least one costume to your project. ### Code tab - Make exactly one "player" sprite. - Give the sprite a behavior that matches the kind of movement you'd like to have. - Press "Run" and make sure you can move your sprite in all four directions.
Click here to preview the different behaviors | moving with arrow keys | driving with arrow keys | being draggable | | ---------------------- | ----------------------- | --------------- | | [][0] | [][1] | [][2] |
. _Extra challenge:_ Change the "player" sprite's speed. (The default speed is 5.)

https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2023/l.short_instructions: Add costumes to your project, then make one "player" sprite and ten "collectible" sprites.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2023/l.long_instructions:
# Create the "Collectibles"

Your game will have at least 10 "collectible" sprites for the player to interact with. You can use a carrot costume for these sprites, or choose something different from the Costumes tab.

## Do This

### Costumes tab

-   _Optional:_ Add another costume to your project.

### Code tab

-   Make at least 10 "collectible" sprite with matching costumes.
-   Use a `set size` to make your "collectible" sprites smaller.
-   _Optional:_ Give your "collectible" sprites a behavior to animate them.

_In this level, your sprites won't interact yet, but that's okay!_

https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2023/l.short_instructions: Use a variable to set the score to 0. Give your "player" sprite a behavior to make it move. Make sure you can move your player sprite all around the play area.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2023/l.long_instructions:
# Track the "score"

The next step is to create a variable to track the player's score.

## Do This

-   Drag a `set` variable block to your workspace.
-   Choose a label for your score variable and set it to 0.

_You won't be able to score any points yet, but that's okay!_

https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2023/l.short_instructions: Add code to remove each "collectible" sprite and score a point each time the sprites touch.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2023/l.long_instructions:
# Removing Sprites

The next steps are to remove your collectible sprites and score points.

## Do This

-   Add a `when touches` event block and set each costume to the ones in your game.
-   Under this event, add code to remove each "collectible" sprite that is touched
-   Use a `change` variable block to score points each time the sprites touch.

_Extra challenge:_ Have your "player" sprite say the current score each time it collects something.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2023/l.short_instructions: After some time has passed, make more sprites for the player to collect.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2023/l.long_instructions:
# More Sprites

At this point, it probably doesn't take long to collect all the sprites in your game. After some time has passed, we'll make more sprites for the player to collect. 

## Do This

-   Add another `at seconds` event block to your workspace and choose an amount of time.
-   Use the `make new sprites` block to create a second group of sprites.
    -   Hint: You might also want to set the size or behaviors of these new sprites.

_Extra Challenge:_ Use a different costume for the new sprites. You'll also need to add another `when touches` event that removes these sprites and scores points.

https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2023/l.short_instructions: After enough time has passed, end the game and show the final score.
https://studio.code.org/s/coursef-2023/l.long_instructions:
# Ending the Game

At this point, your game works! However, we might still want to end the game after enough time has passed.

## Do This

-   Drag another `at seconds` event block to your work space.
-   To end the game, stop all behaviors on the "player" sprite.
-   Use `say` or `print` block to congratulate or thank the user.

_Extra Challenges:_

-   Remove all remaining "collectible" sprites from the screen at the end of the game.
-   Combine your score variable with other text in your message to the player.

dsls.markdown:
# Outbreak: Code Your Own Simulation ## Welcome to Monster Town! Monster Town was usually a happy and healthy place. The monsters of Monster town loved to wander around to visit their friends. One day, one of the monsters started feeling sick. The monster had caught a **virus**! A virus is a tiny germ that can make you sick. The other monsters were not too worried. They kept visiting their friends. Soon after, two more monsters got sick. It was the same virus! It seems they got the virus from their friend. The virus slowly spread to other monsters who were nearby. The healthy monsters began to worry that they were all going to get sick. The sick monsters began to worry that they were going to give the virus to everyone else.
## Stopping the spread Fortunately, after studying the virus, the neighbors of Monster Town made an important discovery. They realized that they were less likely to spread the virus if they wore masks over their mouths. With face masks on, sick monsters were less likely to give the virus to healthy monsters.
## What will happen next? Today, you're going to write code to create and run your own **simulation** of the virus outbreak at Monster Town. A simulation is a computer model of a process or system. Learn to code and make predictions about what will happen to the neighbors of Monster Town. * *How quickly will the virus spread?* * *Will everyone get sick?* * *How will face masks help?* When you're finished, share your simulation with others. Share your message about what you think we can do to help keep others healthy when a virus comes to town.

Write your code in the_ **workspace,** _then press_ **Run** _to see your simulation. If you need any help, click the_ **lightbulb** _for a hint._ ## Do This 1. Make sprites to represent 10 healthy monsters [][0] and 1 sick monster [][1]. **Sprites** are the characters on the screen that can move, change, or interact with each other. 2. Set the size of the sprites to `50`, and make them all begin `wandering`. 3. Press `RUN`. You should see sprites moving around like the animation to the right.

dsls.markdown: # Outbreak: Thinking Like a Scientist Simulations are a great way to learn things that can be hard to observe in the real world. They help scientists solve problems and test new ideas safely and efficiently. Your simulation is a way to show how a virus outbreak in Monster Town might look. ## Reset and Replay! Even when you write the code yourself, it's impossible to know exactly what will happen when you press run. The monsters wander randomly, so you don't know if the virus will spread fast or slow. Whenever you change your code, make sure to run your simulation more than once. Things won't happen the same way twice! ## Collecting Data Try writing down your observations as you run your simulation. You can count the number of monsters that get sick or use a timer to see how fast things happen. For example, how long does it usually take for all monsters to get sick if none have masks? ## Making Predictions If you understand your model, you can use it to make predictions. You can even change how your simulation runs and guess what will happen differently. For example: * What would happen if there were twice as many monsters? * What would happen if the monsters moved at half the speed? ## Is Monster Town like the real world? There is a limit to how realistic any model can get. * What does your outbreak simulation have in common with real world virus outbreaks? * What are the differences? When you finish this activity, discuss these questions with teachers or your family! ## What else can we model? You have already created a working model of the outbreak at Monster Town. What are the things your simulation can't do or show that you wish it could? Press continue to keep going and learn to model even more: * Increasing the number of monsters in the simulation * Helping monsters recover from the virus * Probability, immunity, vaccines, and more! You can also share your simulation model with others, or share a message about what you think we can do to help keep others healthy when a virus comes to town.

# Chance
_Right now, it's impossible for monsters to give or get the virus if either of them is wearing a mask. This sounds great, but it's not really that simple. We should add a "chance" (or probability) for the virus to spread each time any two monsters touch. We can model the chance of getting the virus off of these notes._
Notes:How face masks affect the Monster Town outbreak

_Benefits of Face Masks_ | Healthy | Sick | Chance | | :-----: | :---: | :-----------: | | [][0] | [][1] | **Very High** | | [][2] | [][3] | **High** | | [][4] | [][5] | **Low** | | [][6] | [][7] | **Very Low** |

## Do This 1. Add this **conditional** block under the `when touches` event and set it to a very high chance: [blockly block][8] 2. Add more events that include monsters wearing masks and give each a different percent chance (probability). Click the light bulb for a hint if you are not sure which events are needed. 3. Press **Finish** when you are ready to move on.

Next, you will create a new sprite costume to represent monsters who got a vaccine.
Learn how to modify a sprite costume. | | To modify a costume: | | ------------------------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | [expandable][0]
(Click to view) | 1. Change to the Costumes tab in the top left corner.
2. Duplicate one of the existing costumes.
3. Choose a primary color for drawing.
4. Click the Paint bucket tool, then click the monster's body to recolor it. |
Once the new costume is ready, find a way to work it into your program. For example, you can change masked monsters into vaccinated monsters when they are clicked.
